results.title: Buffalo 66
results.creator_credit: Vincent Gallo, Chris Hanley and Cinepix Film Properties
results.brief_description: Vincent Gallo made his directorial debut with this comedy drama about convict, Billy Brown, who is released from prison after serving a five year sentence for a crime he did not commit. Bitter and prone to violence, Billy is determined to convince his dysfunctional parents that he has been leading a respectable life doing top-secret CIA work. To give his story credibility, he impulsively kidnaps Layla from a tap-dancing class, forcing her to pose as his wife when he returns home for a visit. Layla strangely takes to the role with enthusiasm and remains with Billy even after the parental visit. Cast includes: Vincent Gallo, Christina Ricci, Anjelica Huston, Ben Gazzara, Kevin Corrigan, Mickey Rourke, Rosanna Arquette and Jan-Michael Vincent.

results.title: Bronenosets Potemkin = Battleship Potemkin
results.brief_description:
Made to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the unsuccessful 1905 Revolution, Potemkin initially drew a mixed response in the Soviet Union, condemned by some for its formalism. Its reception abroad ultimately ensured both popular and critical success at home. Nevertheless Potemkin’s influence, if undeniable, has often been overstated. The Odessa Steps sequence’s power to excite rather than move reflects a relatively narrow authoritarian view of art. Eisenstein’s preoccupations with typage in performance and with each change of shot (or succession of changes) in construction had little influence on the development of film narrative. They now seem most relevant to the TV commercial and music clip. Also available on 16mm and VHS.

Credits: Director, Sergei Eisenstein ; photography, Edward Tisse.

results.title: Britannia Hospital
results.creator_credit: Lindsay Anderson, Clive Parsons, Davina Belling and EMI/Parlophone
results.brief_description: Set in a hospital awaiting a royal visit to celebrate its 500th anniversary, this film combines black humour with social criticism to expose the misuse of National Health funds. Malcolm McDowell plays a reporter who sneaks into the hospital with a video camera to capture a mad doctor’s experiments, from funds meant for socialized medicine, to create Frankenstein creatures.

results.title: Bride of Chucky
results.creator_credit: Ronny Yu, David Kirschner, Grace Gilroy and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: This is the fourth, and without a doubt the best in the controversial ‘Child’s play’ series. In the latest instalment Chucky (voiced supplied by Brad Dourif), the benevolent child’s toy is bought back to life in this inventive and witty sequel which plays more like a demented homage to ‘Bride of Frankenstein’. The sinister looking doll which is possessed by the evil spirit of a serial killer is resurrected from the dead by his unbalanced goth girlfriend (played with relish by Jennifer Tilly), who has wedding bells on her mind. However Chucky has more sinister intentions than marriage, when he and his trailer trash bride stow away with two runaway teens wrongly accused of murder. Hong Kong director Ronny Yu (‘Bride with the white hair’), and writer Don Mancini have fashioned a wonderfully irresponsible film which proudly wears it’s horror film references on its sleeve, giving the series some surreal, clever twists and turns. Cast also includes John Ritter, Alexis Arquette and Katherine Heigl.

results.title: Breakfast in Paris
results.brief_description: A high-powered female fashion executive meets a handsome, carefree photographer and their relationship starts with hot glares and cold shoulders. Things don’t get much better for him until the romance of Paris catches up with her. Filmed on location in Paris. Stars Barbara Parkins, Rod Mullinar and Jack Lenoir.

results.title: Breakfast at Tiffany's
results.creator_credit: Blake Edwards, Richard Shepherd, Martin Jurow and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Audrey Hephurn stars as Holly Golightly in the film based on the short story by Truman Capote. Holly’s almost frosty sophistication is only a veneer. Hepburn convey’s Holly’s underlying fragility with poignance and sympathy. George Peppard, as Paul the writer, like Holly is searching to find a place amongst the “fleshpots” and “rats” of New York. As their love blossoms, Paul must come to terms with the fact that Holly is a girl on the run, not only from the past, but from herself. New York, Tiffany’s, Givenchy’s stunning wardrobe for Hepburn, the magical music of Henry Mancini and Johnny Mercer’s song “Moon River”, help make this film a cinema classic. Mickey Rooney as Holly’s slightly deranged Japanese landlord, delights in a hilarious comic cameo.

results.title: Breaker Morant
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Matt Carroll and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: It is 1901, South Africa. The British war against the Boers has deteriorated into bitter guerilla warfare. A unit of the Bushveldt Carbineers, made up mainly of Australians, is ordered by the British High Command to fight the Boers on their terms and take no prisoners, orders that were to prove fatal for Harry Morant. Stars Edward Woodward, Bryan Brown and Jack Thompson with John Waters and Charles Tingwell.

results.title: Brazil
results.creator_credit: Terry Gilliam, Arnon Milchan and Embassy International Pictures
results.brief_description: This nightmarish futuristic satire effectively blurs all lines between illusion and reality. Sam Lowrey, an unambitious government statistician, chooses to ignore the decaying drone-like world around him. Whenever real life becomes too oppressive, Sam fantasizes about being a superhero forever rescuing beautiful Jill Layton. When the omnipresent computer that controls everything in the “real” world malfunctions it causes the mistaken-identity assassination of an innocent citizen. When Sam routinely investigates the error, he meets Jill, literally the girl of his dreams. It turns out, however, that she is an associate of a terrorist whom the computer had originally intended to target for execution. Cast includes: Jonathan Pryce, Michael Palin, Kim Greist, Katherine Helmond, Ian Holm, Bob Hoskins and Robert De Niro.

results.title: Boys on the side
results.creator_credit: Ken Adam, Herbert Ross, Steven Reuther, Arnon Mitchell, Monarchy Enterprises B. V., Heva Productions, New Regency Pictures, Alcor Films, Regency Enterprises and Studio Canal+
results.brief_description: Three women share a car going West and laughs, tears and togetherness unfold along the way. They each have secrets to reveal, strengths to impart and vital moments of self discovery; and their shared friendship subsequently becomes family. Whoopi Goldberg (a wisecracking, lesbian club singer), Mary Louise Parker (a finicky HIV+ real-estate agent) and Drew Barrymore (a free spirit) join forces in this celebration of camaraderie, the art of survival, the gift of laughter and the miracle of friendship and caring by Herbert Ross, the director of The Turning Point and Steel Magnolias. Co-starring Matthew McConaughey, James Remar, Billy Wirth, Anita Gillette, Dennis Boutsikaris, Amy Acquino, Stan Egi and Estelle Parsons.

results.title: Boys don't cry
results.creator_credit: Kimberly Pierce, Christine Vachon, Eva Kolooner, John Hart, Jeffrey Sharp, Hart Sharp Entertainment and Killer Films
results.brief_description: Based on the life and death of Brandon Teena, “Boys Don’t Cry” is a gripping and very moving account of difference and intolerance. Believing herself to really be a male, Brandon constructs a masculine persona for herself and acts and lives as a man in a poverty stricken community in Nebraska. Within this “white trash” locale she attempts to live her identity as best she can. She falls in love with Lana (Chloe Sevigny), a tender romance which results in a group of local young men venting their homophobic violence on the lovers. One of a series of works in late twentieth century American cinema which attempted to deal with the the increasing fracturing and alienation of working class life caused by unemployment and the rationalising of both economics and ethics, “Boys Don’t Cry” resonates deeply as both a story of damaged lives as well being an inspiring challenge to conservative understandings of gender and sexuality. Hilary Swank’s performance as Brandon justifiably won her an Academy Award for Best Actress, and Sevigny’s performance is equally fine. A labour of love for director Pierce, “Boys Don’t Cry” is an exemplary work of Queer Cinema, as well as an outstanding example of the best of American independent film.
